description: From Middle English hanger, haunger, hangere, equivalent to hang +‎ -er. Compare West Frisian hinger (“hanger”), Dutch hanger (“hanger”), German Hänger and Henker.

entries.meaning: One who hangs, or causes to be hanged; a hangman, paper hanger, etc.
A person who attempts suicide by hanging.

definitionGroups.group: That by which a thing is suspended.

entries.meaning: A strap hung to the girdle, by which a dagger or sword is suspended.
(now historical) A short and broad backsword, worn so to hang at the side, especially popular in the 18th century.
examples: I made an offer to  go for my books and chest of clothes, but he swore I should not move out of his sight; and if I did he would cut my throat, at the same time taking his hanger.

entries.meaning: (baseball, slang) A hanging pitch; a pitch (typically a breaking ball or slider) that is poorly executed, hence easy to hit.
(Australian rules football, informal) Synonym of spectacular mark
(climbing) A device secured by a bolt and used to attach a carabiner.
examples: Climbers use anchors or bolts that are already placed in the rock. They clip onto them with metal hangers. Climbers don't need to place the anchors themselves, so they can focus on making the difficult climbing moves.

entries.meaning: (slang) Hunger and anger, especially when the anger is induced by the hunger.
